description: Needed a place to grab a quick snack and coffee before an event. That's when I remember there is a cool looking cafe nearby! Did a search and *gasp* closes in half hour. Rushed over. Got cream cheese bagel and coffee. Price good. Bagel is heated just right, and coffee is good even around closing. Nice barista and environment. Didn't have time to check the succulent garden, but it looks nice at the distance. Will revisit!
author: Amy C.

description:
A wonderfully cool use of space.  Big, lofty, hip, bright!  Nice outdoor seating area. Bring your sunglasses and patience. 

Unfortunately for me, it's also too crowded!  They have a tiny space in which to enter, order food, and I don't care for the way the cream, sugar, and condiments are laid out.  

The regular coffee is made in a large french presses; it gets a little cool for my taste between when they pour a carafe and the time it gets into my hands, when I proceed to douse it with cream. 

It's a generally awkward when I come here for a quick bite or a cup of coffee. I feel like some corporate New Yorker who 'doesn't have time for this!!' 

The menu is great (and small, but changes) for both lunch and dinner, but think of this place as being on the 'slow-food' tip.  I really enjoyed the breakfast sandwich for it's wholesome slices of thick wheat bread, and scrambled egg folded with cheese- it's a great take on the breakfast sammy for $5.75.  Yes, pricey.  

One last comment is they have a space available to rent for events and a catering company in conjunction with the cafe.  I like to imagine holding an even there.  Apparently they have a farm or some sort of property they are cultivating to get food directly for their business, which is super super cool.  A dynamic business.
author: Melissa B.

description:
Stable Cafe. Time and time again.   What can I say, you make good food, at tree sloth speed.  

I ordered a coffee to go, with a croissant.  I could see it there, just across the counter in your well kept pastry display case.  Ordering food is serious business, no need to rush.  In a transaction that easily could have taken 60 seconds, 15 minutes later i walked out w/ my coffee, and croissant.  

Godspeed Stable, to you and your lethargic staff.
author: Matthew N.

description:
The "french press" coffee was terrible. Came out of a pot that had obviously been sitting around all day, and it tasted weak while still being full of grounds. Yuck. 

The sandwiches took a while to come out, but they were very yummy, and came with salad on the side. We had one veggie panini (zucchini) and one roast beef with brie, home-made mustard, and portobello mushroom. I'm not sure why it should have taken so long.

The tables outside have the right combination of sun, shade, and lack of wind, but they were wobbly and the one of the chairs at our table was missing a rung (complete with dangerous metal nubs sticking out). We enjoyed overhearing an animated conversation at the table next to us. On a second visit we might try sitting upstairs instead.
author: Sam Z.

description: quinoa salad is delicous, add chicken if you are quite hungry. Matte latte is yummy as a non-coffee option, upgrade to soy milk and you will thank me.
author: Beth P.

description:
I wanted the poultry in the grilled chicken sandwich. But I also wanted the squash in the veggie sandwich. What to do, what to do.

Solution (as recommend by the friendly guy working the counter): add squash to the grilled chicken. Cost you two quarters more. Done.

My veggie/grilled chicken hybrid was superb, and it came with an unexpected side salad. As for the space, well, I can't really articulate better than I did in my first yelp. It's a beautifully refurbished stable. In the heart of the mission. Done.

I love this place.
author: Jason B.

description:
Very rarely am I inspired to write a Yelp review because of a condiment.  I'm sure it happens on here more than not, but this, I think, is my first time.  I like the salsa at Papalote.  It's got a great texture, good spice, and it is a good compliment to the food they serve.  Some people say it is the best salsa (for it's type) in the city.  I might have agreed at one point...that is until this morning when I went to Stable Cafe.

I will be first to admit I wasn't thrilled with the coffee.  They don't have Splenda or artificial sweetener and no different selection of milks/creams.  Call me a coffee snob.  It's fine.  I am.  I know what I like, and so do you.  

Along with the coffee, however, i got the egg wrap.  It was a huge portion and came with a tiny shot of this chipotle salsa that looked almost exactly like the stuff from Papalote.  It wasn't.  It had way more kick and opened up my eyes and taste buds, the way you'd expect a good cup of coffee to.  This was the winner.  I recommend going to this place, if only to check out the cool atmosphere (free wifi and outdoor seating) and ANYTHING with a side of this chipotle salsa.
author: Adam E.

description:
I came here with a friend on a whim and was pleasantly surprised. This is such a cozy cafe to meet up with friends or work quietly upstairs.  The food is really chill, there's decent parking nearby and the only downfall is that its small. I guess this is why the atmosphere is so cute. 
I had an amazing quinoa salad and my friend opted for the sandwich.  I enjoyed my salad and typically make quinoa for myself twice a week so I know what to expect.  It was healthy, clean and made with alot of TLC.
author: Sarah C.

description: What a wondeful and peaceful place. Sitting out in the garden under the trees, wifi available, very nice people all around, its just fabulous. Also Thomas and Malcom are the heads of Mission Creek and the Stable collective, a culinary incubator that is supporting the local food scene and organizing events. You should check them out. Lovely people with a great mission!
author: Nina M.

description:
I have a studio at ActivSpace, a block away...So stop by here for food/coffee. This is an amazing place, all around. The staff is really great. Very friendly, funny, good people. Matt, david, and another guy whose name I forget. 

The food is unbelievable. Great menu, eclectic. delicious, healthy... eat the Quinoa salad with grill chicken. mmmm. 

Amazing coffee... awesome place to work. HIghly recommend it. Saturday they have bottomless mimosas and amazing brunch.

Beautiful ambience. Great to go work at, grab lunch with a buddy... or bring a date there too. Outdoor seating too.

Only downside: No way to charge your laptop. But understandable, the place is small, you don't want people crowding it up all day.
author: Anish B.

description:
Vivek N. put it well: awesome place, but NO POWER OUTLETS!! I went there hoping to work, but my computer was already dead. They really went out of their way to have no outlets.

Decent coffee, but they really don't want you to work here.
author: Ross A.

description:
This hip Mission Cafe is located less than a block from my office so I typically make at least one trip here each week. With high quality food and a relaxed atmosphere it's a great place for a long lunch with a good book. 

The quinoa vegetable salad is a healthy and delicious choice. They also have a large and varied selection of panini's. All of which are good and made to order - just note when ordering one to go you'll find the small salad that usually accompanies the order is missing - what gives?

*Update: My go to order has become the excellent grilled veggie sandwich. A good mix of vegetables and goat cheese on rye bread. Super so good. Bumping my overall rating up to 4 stars.
author: Abraham W.

description:
I like this place. Good coffee for a good price. Their in-house cup is about the size of a medium and they give you a free refill. I've been here twice and there is usually a line almost out the door each time. It's not too hard to do though, considering it's a fairly small joint on the inside. 

There's an upstairs that has about six tables and a small bar with stools. Down side is that, although they have free wireless, there aren't many (if any) electrical outlets in the place. I sat upstairs both times and never found one, so unless you have extraordinary battery life on your lappy, don't expect to have any nerd marathons. 

The place is clean and well lit, with the charm of it having actually been a livery stable as it's original incarnation. The exposed beams and original fixtures add antiquity to the atmosphere. More of an adult place, I wouldn't really recommend bringing children here, as space is fairly limited and the menu seems to cater to a more mature palate (i.e. not many juices or "kid-friendly" food choices). 

I gave this place 5 stars because they have their own farm where they get much of their produce and their eggs. They are locally sustainable and I find that absolutely charming. The food is good and well-priced, and I liked the general atmosphere. I've never been treated like a dick here, even when I forgot to tip once. 

They usually make/give you your drink right away, then give you a number for your table if you order food. They also bring your food to you, instead of shouting out order numbers. 

I hear they have a pretty awesome patio. It's been too chilly or windy for me to try it out yet, but I plan on frequenting this place and checking it out for myself.
author: Eyva Kid C.

description:
This is a nice little place. If I lived closer and it was more convenient, I'd give it another star. 

First off, the photos will make it seem that the cafe is much bigger than it is.  It's pretty darn small, actually - only about 12 small cafe tables, split between a main and loft level. And while there's also a nice little patio for outside seating, it's not often that it's warm enough to want to sit outside.  

That being said, what is here is actually quite beautiful and well-designed.  The food's delicious, the coffee is tasty, and the space (small as it is) is actually quite airy and nice.   

Wireless is spotty (which I never understand - if you're a cafe/work space kind of thing, please, please PLEASE have solid wireless service, otherwise I can't really do the "work" part of cafe/work).  That would get you another star. 

Parking is kind of a pain, surprisingly.  You wouldn't think this was a particularly busy corner in SF, but there's quite a bit of construction going on in the neighborhood, taking up a lot of available street parking, so be aware of that.  But that should correct itself soon. 

Overall, if you live in/near the neighborhood, it's a great little cafe to come work for a couple hours and get a nice breakfast or lunch.  If you're a little farther away, it may not be worth the trip, but it's still pretty nice.
author: Giacomo D.

description:
Did a random drive by on Folsom Street and I see a really neat cafe that was bullying me to go in.  I needed to kill about 2 hours to do some report writing and work e-mails before meeting up with a colleague for lunch.  I want to try out all the best cafes in SF and for some reason this was going to be one of my faves.  Parking was a nightmare and turning every street corner looking for parallel parking was like waiting in holiday traffic on the 101.  

Finally, I find a spot and even get more excited as I walk into this very clean and modern looking cafe.  There was a short line in front of me, so I decided to step out of an opened side door to be additionally surprised by the outside patio area...instantly thinking about future coffee dates with friends.  I order an Iced Mocha and proceed upstairs, which is basically a loft that overlooks downstairs and provides great opportunities for people watching.  My Iced Mocha was strong, tasty, and the perfect size.  The WiFi is free and the restroom was super clean!  It was a bit warm at first, but they opened up the front door to let a nice breeze come in.  There is potential for a lot of noise from conversations at the tables next to you, but it all depends on the time and if you're sitting near loud people.  

No need to waste your time at chain coffee joints.  If you need free WiFi, in the mood to try out a new trendy spot, enjoy mental breaks to people watch, looking for a place to gossip and catch up with friend(s), and are in the Mission area, then I highly recommend Stable Cafe!  I'm definitely coming back soon!
author: Chad A.

description:
Eat.  The.  Eggs.

Really, they are amazing.

This is a story about Stable Cafe:
http://stretchyhead.com/stable-cafe/
author: S H.

description:
I had been wanting to check this place out since i drove by it not too long ago. I walked in and fell in Love with the decor. Stable says it all! cute little cactus plants and odd and ends. The courtyard outside is sweeet! They had one type of coffee on brew, which was not very good, it was watered down and not very flavorful. Luckily it was for my husband (lightweight coffee drinker) so i thought he should be fine. I ordered him the Nona Morning sandwich. it was open faced and looked so yummy! Reviews from husband, "breakfast was scrumptious, we gotta go there again, as for the coffee, I've had waaay better instant coffee then this". I'll try there espresso next time, perhaps and americano. too bad because i can totally see myself doing work here and parking was super easy around 930 am, its timed too not metered, plus!
unforutunetly though the service wasn't the best either. If they were only nice and smiled more i'm sure they would be busier.  
till next time!
author: Giselle G.

description:
I really wanted to like this place - beautifully designed space, good menu, coffee, outdoor seating.  But, after my 4 or 5 visits there, I have been disappointed. 

- Food is hit or miss.  Some dishes are great, some fall flat.  Also there is a strange portion discrepancy in their $5 regular yogurt & granola which came in what seemed like a 1/3 cup container when ordered to go and the $7 large which was a giant mass of food for a family. 
- Service is very slow. Even ordering a bottled water takes ages. The staff is this mix of "I'm too sexy for this cafe" baristas who will swing back and forth from super nice to completely disinterested and slightly apathetic.
- Coffee. So-so.  Kind of watery on certain visits.
author: Joyce K.

description:
Service is slow and surprisingly rude. I finally got to the counter, smiled and made eye contact with the barista, said hello and was about to order, when he just turned his back to me!  Unbelievable.

A lovely, very young child had just learned how to scream out loud, and so proceeded to demonstrate her ability to do so, roughly every five seconds for the next hour.

I had a cup of coffee, and a refill, and both were swimming with grounds, which is a shame since it's a beautiful space.
author: Adam Z.

description:
Atmosphere:  A+
Very unique.  Very well-done.  Obviously a lot of heart put into this place.  I love the upstairs log/bar at the edge of the balcony, so you can spy on folks coming in.  :o)  Plus, enough different spaces (upstairs, downstairs, outdoor patio) that you can find a place/noise level to suit your needs.

Food:  A- 
A leeetle pricey, but I'm willing to pay for quality.  And it is quality.

Drinks: A-
Again with the price/quality issue.

Service: A
Extremely friendly and helpful.  I know some complain of the service being slow, but in my experience the extra time is being put into creating quality food, drinks, and connecting with customers - basically, creating a great all-around experience.  This is *completely* different from slow service due to ignoring customers, laziness, chatting on cell phones instead of working, etc.  I'll take "slow food" over someone slapping something out of the microwave and onto my plate in the name of speed any day!  If you're in a rush, go to Starbucks.  This is not Starbucks (thank god!).

Internet: D
Fast, free wifi service.  Great!  No outlets.  Double boo.  I work from cafes, and I will happily buy food/drinks all day.  What's wrong with posting signs reminding would-be wifi abusers to buy something every now and then, or that tables kindly be vacated for customers consuming food and beverages during busy hours?  Bummed to not be adding this gem of a cafe to my weekly rotation.
author: Erin M.

description:
This is a lovely cafe to get coffee and brunch at. They have giant floor to ceiling windows and the biggest doors that I have ever seen for something that isn't a wharehouse or palace.  =)

A latte, pastry and sitting on the second floor laptop bar is great to get work done or people watch. 

Minus 1 star for the lack of outlets but the food and atmosphere is great :)
author: Christina L.

description: rude and slow staff spoil the cute outdoor experience.
author: Josie T.

description:
This place has totally gone to shit, and I am very sad to write this review, because I have been a regular here (1-3x/week) for about two years. I have had a lot of food quality and service problems during that time, but I kept going back because I enjoyed the atmosphere, the music, and the eggs and have had a nice rapport with the managers. 

I can really relate to the other reviewer who said: "You've consistently been the only staff in SF that makes me regret tipping."

I've stayed through numerous frustrating incidents including a period in which they were advertising farm fresh eggs but instead secretly substituting factory farmed eggs that were not even organic and a period while they had a front staff member who was so incompetent and stone-headed that he screwed up and/or lost every single order that I ever placed with him, without exception! And, I've stayed even though the quality of the coffee has been very inconsistent, depending on the barista, ranging from undrinkable bitter crap to something that almost approached the quality I'd expect from a proper mission cafe. 

But, now they've replaced that moron with a hostile dick-head who sounds to me like the same person that some other reviewers have been talking about as well, describing as angry and rude. So, a couple weeks ago, I placed an order with him for a cappucino, the same drink by the way that I've been ordering for two years. He took my order then I waited, and waited, and waited, and waited. After waiting for about 30 minutes, I went to the counter and asked one of the managers to confirm that my drink was in the queue. The manager just waved me away and didn't even acknowledge me, while the other rude and hostile barista guy simply ignored me, as per usual. I went back to my seat and waited for another 5-10 minutes. Still nothing. So, I went back, and this time I demanded attention. I spoke directly to him in a firm voice despite his insistent efforts to avoid any eye contact and asked him to confirm that he had my order for a cappucino in the queue. He angrily said "no" and gave me a look like he wanted to pound my face into the floor just for asking. So, I placed an order 35 minutes before for a cappucino, and he told me it wasn't in the queue, so what am I supposed to do, just walk out, and apologize for bothering him? Fuck! So, I told him I'd like my cappucino. He didn't say a word to me. Didn't look at me. Totally ignored me. Then he angrily threw a cup of cappucino on the counter as though I was doing something horrible for asking to have a cappucino that I had ordered and paid for 35 minutes before and after he had served about 6 people who had ordered AFTER me. Not a word. No apology. No comment. Just throws a cappuccino on the counter and ignores me. 

The final straw happened last week when I ordered a potato/egg dish called a tortilla de patatas. This is my favorite dish and something that I've been ordering whenever it was on the menu since I started going there. The quality has always been very inconsistent, but it has always been within the range of being edible. Until last week. After waiting an exceptionally long time to be served (again, something like 30 minutes and after others who ordered after me were already half way through their dishes), I got this thing that was completely unrecognizable. The eggs had apparently been cooked to oblivion. I'm not exaggerating when I say that one could barely tell it was an egg dish. The eggs had the texture of cheap beef jerky. They were 100% totally dry and so hard that I ended up eating them with my hands like they were crackers. It also was not served with the side dish that it's supposed to come with (a dipping sauce). When the dish was thrown down on my table by the hostile asshole barista, he just walked away. I yelled at him while he had his back to me to get his attention and asked him why the side dish wasn't there. He didn't even turn to face me and then said "we don't have it" while he was walking away. No apology. No substitution. No acknowledgement. Why did I eat this, you might be wondering? Because I was fucking starving and had waited so long for any food to be served, and I had to get to work, and I could't bear the thought of facing off with another argument with the asshole barista guy and waiting another 30 minutes for some other dish that will be screwed up in unimaginable ways. So, I sadly sat there and chewed on this monstrosity of an egg plate. How could any chef possibly have produced this? It was not within the range of failure that could be overlooked. 

It's stunning to me why such a loyal customer would be treated with such utter contempt and disrespect. I'm done.
author: Eater S.

description: I don't even like coffee shops, but I love Stable Cafe. It's got character coming out the ears. The front entrance is a huge swinging door. There's a quiet private little place to sit upstairs or if the weather is nice there's a big outdoor seating area. The people who work here are really nice and put me on to the scones fresh out of the oven one day, so now I ask for them every time. I don't know much about coffee so I can't speak to the quality of their beverages, but the food is delicious. Wifi is fast and there's plenty of table space for working. Love this place!
author: Taylor M.

description:
The.Musician.That.Plays.Is.So.Cute. S'pity I was pretty engrossed in my conversation with my friend that I failed to have a proper eye-versation with him but yeah, cute. :)

Both my friend and I had the quinoa salad (I added chicken) which was absolutely yummy even though I am pretty picky with salads meself and I had a house coffee...we sat at the table outside the restroom (cos we classy like that) and chatted long and hard about everything under the sun. The guy next to us was a combination of nosy and amusing and kept interjecting his comments into our sex-commentary.

All in all though, I like the vibe of the place...little bit small, tables a little too close together for a private conversation but whatchu gonna do? Pity I live like 8 blocks of out of the way or it'd be my go-to place. For now it's in my really-like book so I'd definitely hike over to the Stable again!
author: Vanessa C.

description:
I read about Stable on Yelp and thought I check it out today.  What an awesome space for a coffee shop!  I can easily see myself coming back here with my laptop and hanging out for a couple of hours.  

The ceiling is about 20ft high with huge ~15ft windows on the street side of the building.  The interior is loft like, modern industrial with a lot of rustic timber and steel with seatings on 2 levels.  Interior seating is limited but there are 5-6 tables outside as well.  The Wifi is free which is a huge plus.    

I ordered a Ham & Swiss Panini which comes with a side of mixed salad with vinaigarette dressing.  The paninis come on french bread which is an interesting twist.  It was good but on the small side.  At 6.75 though, it's pretty reasonable.  

The small French Press coffee at 1.75 was reasonable.  The coffee was good, but not great.  I'll try their Espresso next time. 

Parking was not difficult, at least on an early Friday afternoon.  3.5 stars for the coffee, 4 stars for the sandwich and salad, and 5 stars for the space!

I'll be back with my laptop to write more Yelp reviews here!

3.5-4 stars for coffee, 4 for the panini I had, 4 for atmosphere.

P.S. - I was told by other Yelpers that there are not AC outlets for laptops in the dining room.  So, bring extra batteries if you have them!
author: Paul K.

description: DELICIOUS!! I would highly recommend the chicken pesto provolone panini, with a ginger molasses cookie. The seating is superb. Such a cute and calming atmosphere.
author: Eleonor W.

description:
First, let me be clear.  My caffeine delivery system must be swift and sure.  Any interruption in the delivery or anticipated delivery method, particularly of the first dose of the day can cause my rage-o-meeter to spike.  

I really want to like this place.  And there are lots of things to like:

-super nifty space
-fast free wifi (get the code from the register)
-all organic all the time
-super tasty coffee & food
-cute staff boys who are quite sweet

So why only 2 stars?  Well, NEVER go here if you are in a hurry.  Or on any kind of schedule. Or just in dire need of your first caffeine dose of the day.  I've given Stable cafe 3 chances and each time the same thing, a looonnnngggg wait for my coffee.  

I don't need my late to be a freakin' work of art.  I actually watched the barista (o? Is this a gender specific word?) THROW AWAY my late and start over because it was apparently not up to artistic standards.  Clearly he had no idea how near death this carried him as my brain screamed NOOOOOOOOOOO!!!!

Just now I watched a couple pace up & down the stairs waiting for their drinks, the one appologizing to the other "I know you've got to get going" and him saying "it's ok, but I will have to get going probably as soon as our drinks come"

The 2nd time I was here I got a french press thinking it would be 1) faster & 2) come in a nifty french press.  Wrong on both counts.  The coffee is made in a french press and then put into thermos pumps.  And you get a cup out of a thermos pump.  I love the magic of the french press -- watching it, pushing it down, ok I confess - I'm a gaget nerd.  So to me, a coffee made at some point in the last hour or so poured from a thermos and presented to me in a cup is not a french press cup of coffee.  That's just me.

While the staff boys are cute & very sweet, they seem to be hesitant & well, slow.  They keep looking at each other to figure out who's doing what & how to do things.  And this place has been open for QUITE some time now.

And lastly... it's expensive.  $3.29 for a small late.  I realize this may be a Starbucks price, but my local cafe only charges 2.25 (tax included) for a late.  Not $3.00 + tax.  I guess I'm paying for art.  


So do go here if you enjoy caffeine as a work of art.  Probably don't go here if you need caffeine to live 'cause you might die first.
author: nomi c.

description:
great set up inside and out - the only thing is we ordered CHICKEN PANINI's and it was the lamest panini i have ever had... it was only the baguette roll with a dry piece of chicken and some melted cheese

VERY DISAPPOINTED....i expected something a little more interesting..

please make your panini more interesting !!!.
author: Floza S.

description:
SO. MUCH. FOOD. Seriously. I've been here for lunch and brunch, and both times it's been delicious. Delicious and inexpensive. At times, Stable can get crowded, but if you score a patio table, it's worth it. Far enough from other patrons that you can catch up with your friend who is giving you a play-by-play rundown of what she did in that SF dark alley the night before, but close enough to gawk at all the great looking, muscle sporting shirtless guys who walk back and forth from the street to the construction site on the patio. However, if you have to sit inside you might risk entertaining others with your conversation. 
Will review again when the construction is over, sans shirtless guys. My guess: I'll probably dock it a half star.
author: Jen A.

description:
Delicious coffee, which counts for a lot. I like that they have the proper little cups to serve espresso. 

The layout is awesome. I love sitting upstairs and watching out the massive windows. You never know what you're gonna see around this area.

The food is great. Fairly simple, super fresh ingredients. It's hard to go wrong with their paninis. This was the first place I learned of the heavenly goat cheese and fig combo that now dominates my cheese plates. Their quinoa salad is also fabulous. Loads of freshly grilled veggies with a delicious citrus dressing. The soups are usually spot-on, too.

A great place to come and do some work or just people watch. The music in the background is always pleasant and low key, usually with a decent amount of indie. Last time I was there it was the Antlers.
author: Monica C.

description: Very good, despite the rampant typos on menus and signage. Love the outdoor seating.
author: Hella Stella Y.

description:
I LOVE the food at Stable Cafe.

They let you order a big mixed green salad and you get to PICK YOUR INGREDIENTS!
So you only have to eat what you want! Instead of picking through the salad or saying, No this, No that.

I am so picky that this is a godsend for me.

Also, the atmosphere is really cool. Great decor.

It does get too hot in there sometimes. And the fact that they close at 4pm is inconvenient esp because I usually want their salads for dinner.

But all in all, great, hip place
author: Alicia D.

description:
(i joined yelp just to add this review.. for justice)

Honestly the worst cafe experience i've had in San Francisco. I was excited to check it out, as its on my new commute to work. My mistake, i will never go back in there.

I walk in and there's six people in line, although there are plenty of people working, only one guy is slowly taking orders and making drinks.  It takes me 15 mins to get to the front of the line, so i ordered a pre-assembled sandwich and ask them to heat it up.  It was 6.50 for a croissant ham and cheese (RIPOFF), but, to add insult to injury, another dollar for a credit charge. 

I sat down and waiting another 10 mins for my ham and cheese sandwich to be heated before getting up and asking the manager is i can have it cold or not. The manager was a pompous dick. 

This place fucking blows. Stable cafe has a good atmosphere, all at the cost of their service and quality. DON'T GO THERE.

Oh yeah, as for the hame sandwich, it sucked. I wouldn't feed it to my dog.
author: daniel a.

description:
Oh yes.

Me: Can I get a double iced mocha?
Barista: Sure. Whole milk?
Me: Whatever has the most fat.
Barista: How about I step it up to half-and-half?
Me: Sure!

After talking with me to figure out just how much chocolate I wanted in my mocha, he proceeded to make me the most amazing iced mocha ever. On top of that, the shortbread cookie I had was delicious, and I love the space (to be fair, I like any coffeeshops with two stories).

Also my first introduction to De La Paz beans - they are now added to my former trinity of Bay Area Coffee roasters with Blue Bottle, Ritual, and Verve.
author: Mark A.

description:
I went back today with a friend who works in the neighborhood;  she was on her lunch hour and I had my dog, so she suggested Stable Cafe.

Once again I was struck by what a truly wonderful space this is, both inside and out.  

I had a croissant, and thought I would give the French press another try.  This time, I asked how long they steep it and they said 4 minutes.  I asked if I could have my own french press and they said no, they don't do it that way.  Then they poured my coffee from a big urn.  I don't quite get how they make french press and dispense it from an urn, but - whatever!

Unfortunately before I even tried the coffee, which was served in a glass, I was turned off by how light in color it was.  Like, I do not want to be able to look through a glass cup filled with coffee and be able to see what is on the other side!

I kind of channeled my inner child and found myself saying out loud "No.  No.  No."  Then I gathered my wits and said I knew I wouldn't like it and could they sub in something else.  The barista came over and said "did you drink any?" and I said "no I didn't touch it!" which the other guy verified, so he poured it back in the urn.

They made me an Americano instead, and the barista, who was pretty nice, considering, talked to me about the coffee they make there.  He said they use Guatemala coffee which is lighter but has more caffeine.

Because I thought it was perhaps unfair to judge a coffee on appearances, I asked for a taste of the french press and they gave me some and I really did not like it at all.

Unfortunately, the Americano was just awful also. Weak, tangy, but didn't taste like any coffee I have ever had before.   Truly, I felt like I was in an episode of Punkd and somebody was going to pop out from behind a door and say "just kidding!  It really is dishwater, we just wanted to see if we could get you to believe us if we talked it up enough."

So, props for the food (I had a croissant which was very good), the ambiance (off the hook), and the barista who was kind enough to tell me about their coffee in a way that made me think yes, they really do care about their coffee.  And I will absolutely concede that maybe it is great coffee, if that's the style you like.  But to me, with my palate that is used to Peet's French roast, it tasted like dishwater.  Such a bummer, I would absolutely stop in here every time I visited the Mission if the coffee were more to my liking...
author: Alexandra D.

description: Love what they did with the space, the monstrous windowed doors are cool and allow sunlight to wash over the cafe.Their ham sandwich was delish! Very fresh, high quality ingredients were used throughout. The guy working the register had a laid back vibe and was very friendly. Looking forward to coming back, think they might actually deserve a coveted Stoppelman 5 star... I'm going to have to give it another try before I commit, stay tuned.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
This place is worth checking out for the unique architectural transformation from historic horse stable to cafe.  Plus there's outdoor seating that is NOT on the sidewalk.

The food is pretty good, but there's plenty of room for improvement.  My toasted roast beef sammy was drrrrrrrryyy.  Latte decent.  Quinoa salad quite good.  Prices are on the upside of reasonable.  Any more and it'd be too expensive.

I wish the studiously mellow help would step it up on the service level and at least look like they're moving and can do two things at once.   It seems to be the mindset of everyone behind the counter.  Nice people, it just seems to have a "I'll get to it in my own mellow time" vibe to it -- as if it's part of the requirements to work there.

Without the architecture and design, this place would be just slightly above average.

I had previously given this place three stars, but I have since had their delicious asparagus sammy with egg on top.  I'm giving an extra star for that.  

The help still need to move faster.
author: Paul S.

description:
In these turbulent times, all of us are looking for a little stability.  Well, I hate to disappoint you: you will not find it at Stable Cafe.  The Cafe is so named because it used to be, in fact, one of Mayor Phelan's stables.  Don't worry, though: the horses and the smell that usually accompanies them is long gone.

What you have here is a cafe that looks like one of the super modern SOMA lofts with an espresso machine and a kitchen.  The decor here is industrial chic at its finest: exposed brick, stainless steel and wood accents.  The ceilings are very high, which creates an illusion of space and openness.  As soon as you walk in, you are faced with a couple of choices: should you order the food first or get a table first.  The counter is right in front of you, with small, yet sufficient seating areas located to the right of the entrance and upstairs.  The upstairs seating area is a little bit darker and slightly more intimate.  Small square tables could be rearranged for your convenience.  My biggest complaint is the lack of actual chairs.  They do offer stools for your seating pleasure, but a stool doesn't exactly say "come stay awhile," unless you're Norm Peterson of Cheers.

For lunch I ordered a chicken sandwich, which was $8 and change.  It's a great value for a pretty big sandwich served with some tossed mixed greens on the side.  The salad tasted super fresh.  If that's the taste of organic greens, then I would seriously consider switching.  The chicken sandwich was pretty big, although the chicken breast was a tad on the dry side.  The roasted peppers and spicy mustard helped offset the lack of juiciness, but I still noticed it in every bite.  I did enjoy, however, how white the chicken breast was.  That always signifies "fresh and natural."

The employees and patrons of Stable Cafe were really, really nice.  Everyone was extremely helpful and friendly.  I know I shouldn't be surprised, but you know how it is with trendy places that try too hard.  I definitely did not feel that way at Stable Cafe.

If you are looking for a light and inexpensive lunch option in the Mission, give Stable Cafe a try.
author: Yan G.

description: I was pleasantly surprised by this place! They have a great brunch menu that is healthy and light. Amazing breakfast sandwiches and yummy fresh salads. They a few tables inside but have an open outdoor patio where you can relax in the sun. Pretty chill environment, I don't live in the neighborhood but am definitely making the trek back here for brunch.
author: Kristi E.

description:
Yummy locally grown food!!!

A friend and I shared an arugala salad and a goat cheese & asparagus sandwich.  The sandwich had the option of coming with an egg on top, which apparently comes from a farm they own!  I would have loved to have chatted it up with the staff to learn more about their model.  What was apparent is that the food was cheap, local and gooood!  

Didn't get to try the sweets but will next time.  The cucumber lemonade is refreshing!
author: Gigi S.

description: This place does my favorite brunch in all of San Francisco. Everything that comes out of that kitchen tastes fresh and delicious. Their breakfast foods on Sundays are heavenly, and their scones are to die for. They are the best scones I have ever had, anywhere.
author: P Z.

description: Pretty solid place with healthier choices than most of the spots in this neighborhood.  Nice mix of beverages, breakfast, a few salads and sandwiches. Very clean. Great outdoor patio. Service is friendly and fast. Salad portions seem much bigger if you eat in instead of to-go. I will definitely go back but eat in next time.
author: Lauren S.

description:
Airy, spacious, light-filled, with seating upstairs, downstairs, or outside.  The coffee is very good and they made a pretty pattern with the foam atop my latte.  I always find that charming.  I later had a very tasty hibiscus agua fresca. The menu looked good, but I didn't try any of the dishes.

There is wifi (password available at the register) but no outlets for your gadgets.  Motorcycle parking is available right outside and three Vespas occupied the spaces while I was there.  No bike parking is especially convenient, but I did see one patron wheel his bike inside and lock it to the railing adjacent the entrance.
author: Mandy H.

description:
This place drives me crazy. The food is good but the service is THE WORST. 

None of the staff know how to work the register. Customers spend hours trying to decide what to get and asking stupid questions like whether the chicken was killed humanely. 

I work around the corner and have made the mistake too many times of popping in for a sandwich or coffee. I always end up seething with rage, waiting endlessly while some nincompoop tries to order a sandwich or the dingbat server screws up the register.

No more. I will only go in there if there are NO OTHER CUSTOMERS IN LINE. Trust me -- you have to be the only customer, or you will not get served in this lifetime.

Go around the corner to the Soccer Cafe on 16TH ST. It's not trendy, but the Chicken Breast sandwich is awesome. http://www.yelp.com/biz/soccer-cafe-san-francisco
author: Leander K.

description:
so smart. just barely convert a building in a low rent district into an airy open space w/loft seating, leave the rough and tumble feel of an unfinished house, but put in striking artwork and daily fresh flowers.   Be friendly,  serve good food, take AMEX.  They will come, and you will thrive.

come here and sit a while.  feel like a designer equine. 

on my last visit there was some construction in the small adjacent empty lot.  is an outdoor patio coming next?
author: Nikki F.

description: Cool layout with funky split level seating up front with an awesome patio with pies out back but the slow ass internet tanked this rating.  Deduct another star for closing at 4 pm on a Saturday.  Left this place and went straight to Coffee Bar and never looked back.
author: Shaun L.

description: I visited this little spot and met up with my cousin here about a month ago when touring SF.  I'm a sucker for plants, for the outdoor garden was a nice little touch.  I had the quinoa which was light and refreshing, yet filling.  It's only a couple minutes walk away from the BART.
author: Janina R.

description:
Pretty good. If you're looking for a place to work from all day, this is not for you. But if you want some delicious coffee and a place to rest for while, then two thumbs up. There is free wifi but not a single plug available, so come fully charged if you need to use your laptop. 

I'd also recommend basically anything on their menu.
author: April B.

description: Just had the eggplant sandwich.  It was really yummy.  Really like the patio options as well.
author: Jeni S.

description: Low flavor. Got the Nona (egg, tomato, cheese) but just had very little other than throwing those ingredients together. The music was pretty loud for working as well. Cant judge the coffee but was a bad fit to grab breakfast and start my day
author: Ojus P.

description: Great food, great atmosphere.  Just know there no power plugs.
author: michelle h.

description:
The owner must be a perfectionist, because stable cafe is flawless.

It's trendy without being pretentious, fast without being pre-made, and fresh without being overpriced. 

the menu is vegetarian friendly, but meat-lovers still have plenty of options.  Bring your laptop, too. It's a great place to get some work done while filling up.
author: Zuzzi E.

description:
I went here with my husband based on curiosity, the good reviews and the close proximity to my work. I won't go back. There are other cafes nearby that are much better and for less money.

The latte I got was bitter and sour. The only thing that would cause your latte to taste like this is an unclean machine. I also asked for a cup of fruit and they told me that they could not sell me fruit as it was only for garnishment. I couldn't help but feel disgruntled in lieu of this. We live in an amazing city that prides itself on its access to fresh local produce and this hip cafe couldn't sell me with a cup of fresh fruit. Being that I was hungry and needed something for breakfast I went with the $4.50 toast which sadly came with a small side of unsalted butter and a huge serving of four large pieces of bread and a few blueberries for garnish (okay, okay I guess I got a little fruit after all).  

The other thing that peeved was the fact that the counter person/barista was talking to the guy behind us in line, telling him how he was working on his order as he spoke, and as we stood there at the counter first in line, money in hand. I think this constitutes as rude.  

I thought about giving it one star but I must admit that I liked that look of the place so I felt it was only fair to give it another star for decor.

However, I won't be going back.
author: Sera M.

description:
Best lattes in the neighborhood (even better than Coffee Bar).  Always foamy, not too hot, and never bitter.  

Staff is sometimes a little spacey (forgotten drinks, long waits, and one time, a strange charge on my debit card - but they were VERY nice about fixing it).

Food is great but pricier than I usually like to spend on lunch.  Sometimes, when I'm having a rough morning, I go for the rich, delicious, soul-soothing egg-in-the-hole sandwich.
author: Kat W.

description: been going to Stable for a few years so i've seen some changes, all GOOD changes. the food has always been consistent but the service has really picked up lately. nice friendly baristas, hot guys and cute friendly girls to start my day. I'll keep coming for the food and the amazing atmosphere. keep up the good work!
author: Grace Anne A.

description: On a recent random wandering through Mission, I stumbled upon Stable Cafe. Their menu offerings for breakfast, especially the quiche selections, were right on time. I also like that there's a courtyard where customers can dine. Good stuff. I've been there a couple of times, so I'll definitely return.
author: Jen A.

description: I dig the ambiance and enjoyed the chat with staff while waiting.  Three Babes Bakesop out back is a bonus and it was fun to be at the Stable while Food Network was filming. Cool concept. Neeeigh. I am a fan.
author: Doc R.

description: dropped by for lunch. the paninis were okay, the quinoa salad was delicious.
author: Long C.

description:
When I was a teenager (read: age 13) - my mom decided that getting me out of bed every morning was her life's work, and was making her miserable.  I simply could not wake up, and it mattered none at all what time I went to bed.  Ten hours or 3 hours of sleep - I'd still be hard to wake up.

So at this precious age, she decided one morning that she would bring me coffee to force me to take a sip in hopes of making HER life easier.   Back then - her coffee was as sweet as caramel -  and on this momentous day started an addiction that has grown to DEFINE me to this date (and probably stunted my growth too - I might have been way taller than 5'7" if not for this detrimental act by my mother).  

Granted, back then it was Yuban - and that was good enough.  Now, I'm ready to go to Ethiopia to pick and roast my own beans to make myself a real cup of coffee.  

Some people do heroine, others smoke pot - -  I drink coffee.

My love for coffee is second to none, it knows no boundaries, and it must be had first thing in the morning.

Here's my review on Starbucks, in general:
http://www.yelp.com/biz/starbucks-coffee-company-seattle-21#hrid:KvXoHdOKb7h6porFguGZuw

A love affair.
Coffee is my second religion, right after Christianity.

Well, on a nice afternoon in San Francisco, after lunch - Jon suggested a new coffee place he was digging.  He had me at "co-" - - say no more, let's go.

What's cool about Stable Cafe is the decor.  Open, lofty, lots of wood, two floors, and good light.  Serving french press coffee is delightful.

What's not cool about this place is - - - no outdoor seating (coffee is so much better in open air), uncomfortable seating (all wooden chairs or stools), and limited space resulting in no privacy.  I am all about drinking my coffee and having my mind relaxed, and my butt comfortable.  My butt was not comfortable here.

Without a patio, I can't rate this place as 5-stars, but it serves up good coffee and service is very friendly.  People in the Mission seem to hang here to work/read or what have you - and it's obviously a cool neighborhood joint.

Taste-wise, I prefer Blue Bottle Coffee.
But it's less hype here, good coffee, and much better prices than the exorbitant prices that Blue Bottle charges.

As much as I am into these little cafes - I still prefer a big Starbucks with huge covered outdoor seating.  It's unfortunate when you can't take advantage of the amazing weather SF has - - cold, brisk air blowing while you drink in a hot cup of Joe.....  it's like a dream come true!
author: Grace K.

description:
I love this place. Small and quaint. 

I had the special...the Stable Cobb salad. Fantastic! Creative, large portion, and 10 bucks, 

Get to SF and try this gem.
author: Steve P.

description:
My friend and I stopped by here for a quick lunch. She ordered the quinoa salad, and even though I thought that sounded good, I ordered the arugula salad. But when they brought out our order, they gave us two arugula salads. No big deal, of course, everyone makes mistakes. So I said, oh, wait, she ordered the quinoa salad, assuming he'd apologize and take it back. Instead, he said, "No, it was two arugula salads" and showed me the ticket. I said, "No, she ordered the quinoa." Then he agreed to take her salad back, but so unpleasantly that my friend was worried he'd spit in it.

Then, I went to grab us silverware after he went back inside, the cashier saw me and said, "I heard two arugula salads." What?! TWO staff members are ARGUING with me about what we ordered? I said, "Well, she said quinoa." And then he said AGAIN, "No, she said arugula." REALLY? I shrugged and said, "Nope, quinoa." Then he muttered something to the girl at the counter and she laughed and looked back at me. I said "excuse me?" but he just chuckled and wouldn't repeat it.

I had to argue with two staff members over their mistake to get our order! With that kind of hostile customer service, we definitely won't be going back.

Oh, AND the ice tea tasted weird, kind of yeasty, like it was fermented.
author: Laura H.

description: One of my favorite spots in the city. Love the atmosphere, food is great, and so is the coffee!
author: Michal W.

description:
Love, love, love the ambiance! I have walked by this place a gazillion times and every time I pass it all I want to do is play hooky, go inside, order breakfast, lunch, and dinner, and curl up somewhere comfy with a good book. 

I also met the owner, who is super cool, and really appreciate the fact that he's infused menu choices from travels he's made to South America. The decor is also influenced from his trips and it is a SUPERB space. 

As I'm writing this I just want to leave work and spend the rest of the day at Stable!
author: Swetha G.

description: I was surprised that the cashier stole $2 from the register right in front of me.  He probably thought I wasn't looking, or that I wasn't familiar with the "type in the price, then hit no-sale" technique.  He probably gets few tips for $2.75 cups of ordinary coffee, and decided to take matters into his own hands.  Anyway, it's tacky, and should not be done in front of customers.
author: S C.

description: This place is amazing, I've never seen this kind of cafe in downtown. Garden is really nice.
author: Ege O.

description:
I've ridden by this place almost every day for the past two months and hadn't noticed it. That is a tragedy, because I've been missing out on a quality cafe experience. As you can see, I've given five stars to a cafe. This is not my style, but I feel it is warranted. 

First off, the baristas are really, really nice and they make a great pressed yerba mate. Second, the design is fabulous. I love the floors and massive i-beams (wish they would post a write-up in the history of the building). Third, the breakfast items and lunch specials are delicious. I recommend the hot cereal. It comes with massive raspberries. This is a five star cafe, if there ever was one. Nicely done.
author: Regina S.

description:
Just your typical trendy coffee shop full of privileged white people. Nice atmosphere, coffee was OK, didn't try the food -- but it looked good. 

But here's why Stable only gets two stars: terrible service. I ordered two coffee drinks. There was no line, and yet I had to wait about 10 to 15 minutes for my coffee. 

The staff were clearly more interested in socializing with one another than with helping the customers. I watched in horror as one waiter chatted up the barista constantly, so much that the barista couldn't do his job. I even heard the barista complain that he was making mistakes because people were talking to him. Great.

 So the cook in the back got a mocha, and the chatty waiter in the front finally got an espresso. That took about ten minutes, I'd estimate. Then I complained. Five minutes later we got our coffee. To his credit, the barista did apologize, but I simply told him "I won't be back, there are a lot of choices in this town."

And it's true. If I want bad service, I can go to Atlas. Their coffee is better.
author: Weasel F.

description:
Nothing gives me a more sour taste on a place than outright disrespect.

My girlfriend and I walked in the afternoon on a Saturday and it was slow. We waited in line behind one person and our excitement did not waver as the counterperson had to make coffee on his own while one guy out in the patio was on a break and one guy in the back was doing who knows. 

In 5 minutes my gf and I hang back having been acknowledged by the counter-guy that we were next. Another couple comes in and steps up to the counter and attempts to order. The red b-ball cap says he will be with them in one moment but informs that we were next. 

Fine. 

So two minutes later he turns around ready to go and ignores us and goes to the new couple and takes their order!

What the hell? 

So  I make my presence felt after that bizarre slight but somehow I managed to turn myself and my gf invisible and mute.

We went to Ritual Coffee Roasters on Valencia and we got not only good coffee but courtesy and respect.
author: Matthew S.

description: Nice atmosphere, good coffee, and really good brunch type food for a casual place. I got the salami/pickle panini and a macchiato. yum!
author: Claire b.

description:
This cafe is crazy cute. There's just no other way to say it. 

If I lived in San Francisco and had some sort of freelance job, I would totally post up here for hours on end. The space is open and bright - so inviting, especially on a sunny day and the guy that works the front (both times I've gone) seems very sweet. 

I've had the ham sandwich and the quinoa salad - definitely prefer the quinoa. It has goat cheese and roasted veggies and it's a pretty huge portion. However, I think the real draw here is the coffee and pastry combo. Their cookies are amazing! There's one called the sand angel I believe and it tastes like a cross between a snickerdoodle, a ginger cookie and a graham cracker. Trust me, it's delicious and chewy and everything you could ever want in a cookie (unless you're one of those silly people that likes their cookies crispy). The peanut butter cookie is also pretty awesome. 

My cappucino was perfect and they even have yerba mate! 

I'm almost salivating just thinking about those cookies...
author: Alli J.

description:
I went to Stable Cafe for the first time last Monday, Memorial Day.  My friends and I arrived at 11am.  When we got to the counter, we were informed that they were no longer serving breakfast.  We were also informed that they do not have decaf coffee (I know, why decaf?; but that is what all 3 of us drink).  Then we were informed that they were out of hot chocolate.  3 strikes!!
I really think cafes that serve breakfast should do so later than 11am, especially on a holiday.
And the staff were quite spacey and somewhat slow in providing the few things we could/did order.
It is a shame.  Stable is a beautiful place, great design, interestingly laid out, an outside area, and it is not being run well.  I will not return.
author: Ruth N.

description:
Stable, I love your coffee and your food. But your service needs A LOT of help. I was a loyal customer, grinning and bearing the fact that even getting a cup of coffee to go is a 10-minute investment. 

But then you had to go and hire that really surly counter guy -- he's probably 35, short, Latino and RUDE. He is so unpleasant that I don't want to come back.

How is it that you can put so much care into your design and food and let it be ruined by such terrible, and sometimes downright hostile, service?

A couple of tips:

1. Acknowledge the customers presence, even if you are busy doing something else.

2. Do not let customer stand there waiting for you to at least acknowledge her while you eat/gossip.

3. Do not look through customer (who has by now been waiting without being acknowledged for minutes) to the person behind her and ask them what they want because they're your friend.
author: ceecee m.

description:
All I have to say is, what took me so long? I've been walking past this place for over a year, when I thought it was a private home being remodelled by historian owners who just really wanted you to know it had once been a "STABLE." But lucky for me it wasn't. What a lovely space, all simplicity and openness, with even lovelier food inside. For lunch I had the veggie sandwich on wheat.  A delicately dressed salad of fresh greens and shaved carrots accompanied my stuffed-to-the-gills sandwich, packed with grilled squash, zucchini, tomato, grainy mustard, at least 12 pounds of goat cheese (there was a LOT of goat cheese), and the best pesto I have ever had (since I declared over 15 years ago that Sam's Club sold the best pesto I had ever had). 

After finishing my sandwich, I decided to take a treat to go. While I'm sure the lavender salted shortbread is very tasty and grownup, what could I do when faced with a peppermint chocolate cookie? Well aware that one bad cookie could diminish the enlightening lunch I just had, I took the risk anyways and was rewarded with what I can only describe as a thin mint. If that thin mint had been kidnapped by the witch from Hansel and Gretel, then held captive and fattened up on Godiva for a month. It was also big enough that a more restrained person could have saved half for later (ha!)
author: Hallie R.

description:
Great woodsy interior (did it used to be a stable?) and sunny outdoor seating area. The sandwiches are simple and delicious, carried by high quality ingredients and tasteful combinations of ingredients (meats, brie, and flavorful roasted peppers are typical).

Accommodates work (best upstairs) and socializing (best outside). On weekends, Three Babes sells their pies by the slice right on Stable's grounds.

Spotty wifi, no outlets.
author: Charlie Bolognese Z.

description: Excellent lunch spot. Super service. Had the quinoa salad and empanadas, both very good. It also looks like the espresso would be excellent.
author: Will S.

description:
Working as I do at Mariposa and Bryant, I have found the neighborhood sorely lacking in good lunch spots that are do-able in an hour, so I was glad to read about Stable opening up.

I think this was their opening day, as the order-taker didn't know what meats they had on the sandwiches, but I lucked out and ordered a salami and avocado sandwich on focaccia that was very good - the salami could have come from some fancy-shmancy salumi plate.

The cafe itself is small but feels expansive, as it has very high ceilings and a small second level.

My friend ordered a bowl of gazpacho - I tasted it and liked it - and a nice-looking veggie panini.

I'm going back soon!
author: Kevin C.

description:
It was a gloriously beautiful day in the city and for some reason, I got it in my head that I was going to walk from downtown (425 Market) to the Stable Cafe.  Really just a little more than 2 miles!

So, by the time arrived at cafe, I was both a little sweaty and plenty hungry!  The menu looked really tantalizing and couldn't decide what to order to I asked the cashier for a rec from the list of sandwiches.  It sounded like a pretty ringing endorsement of the roast beef and brie, so I went for it.   And the sandwich was mighty tasty...but a little confusing with all the flavors that were going on with the mustard seeds and red onions, the brie was overshadowed.  Altogether all of the ingredients seemed super fresh. 

I loved the ambiance. It's a place that I would consider sitting for a couple of hours with my beloved laptop.
author: Evelyn K.

description:
WOW ...where to start!
A real find for the area, the building has been redone and opened up to a bright airy cafe with amazing food, coffee and desserts that are to die for.  The large windows in the front and the second floor area make the space seem twice as large.
Went there today with some friends and had the chicken panini with a small side salad it was delicious and very filling- but that did not stop me from trying my friends vegetable puree soup- again amazing tasty yet not too heavy.  Had he seven layer bar for dessert and all I can say is I will be back for more.
The staff is friendly and very outgoing. 
I will be back again to The Stable Cafe.
author: Ron L.

description:
STABLE is one of those places that you want to keep all to yourself. I have been going there for over a year, almost everyday and this weekend it was packed and loud and it made one staff member just a *little* cranky.  It's forgiveable. I would have been cranky too. 

This is the best cafe in the city because it's a place to go with a friend and you have privacy, somehow just because of how the space has been designed. I love going here to see Matt and Davis, but secondly -- the architecture is outstanding. 

The food - always great. I never get tired of their food and the coffee is strong, like streetcar. 

Well...  I wish people wouldn't go here and I could be their only customer.  But that would be bad.
author: Veronica V.

description: Love this place. Very simple menu but nice staff, great coffee. The cafe is super cute! The top / loft area is perfect for working and they have a beautiful outdoor area.
author: Claire R.

description: I really love the Stable Cafe.  Now, I am a sucker for good design that creates community and that is exactly what Malcolm Davis has done.  He took this old decrepit building that once housed the mayor's horses and turned it into this mecca for creativity and invention.  The food is gourmet, but my favorite part has been seeing the place evolve, and now there is a great patio space outside.  Plus, I go there almost expecting to find Bay Area celebs- oh, there's David Baker sitting by the window, or there is Malcolm outside talking with a colleague... but my disappointment has been the time I just missed meeting Flora Grubb, as I heard she had just left.  Rats!
author: Jason S.

description:
This Place is absolutly amazing!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Chef Thomas and his team are very professional and efficient!

I had a blast in this restaurant!!
author: Ketrin H.

description:
I love this place! 
I went to there in this morning for having a breakfast.
First, I saw the hip interior. Each objects has very nice sense and it made a very nice atmosphere in the cafe. There were pretty lots of costumers  who wants to hot cafe.
The food was pretty good, not great. We ate apple cake and egg omelets.  It was small potion though, we satisfied.
I will definitely go there again!
author: ako h.

description: DELICIOUS GOODNESS!!! Chatted with the owner and found out he has his own chicken farm. He was super nice and the food was so fresh and good. I got the Mushroom with goat cheese panini. The bread even had walnuts in it! They used organic honey in their lattes and it was tasty!
author: Mai N.

description: I used to love going to stable and grabbing their Pomba in the morning. I'd randomly wander in some days for lunch, its a nice place to sit and people watch. I like how it really does feel kind of like a stable. And the cute guys working the cash wrap make it that much more fun.
author: Analisa S.

description:
Fantastic space in the Mission with quality food and great baked goods. Historic character to the building renovated as a charming space. 

Visited: weekday mornings 
What I've tried:  Coffee cake, sand angel cookie, brownie, peanut butter choc. chip cookie, sea salt lavender shortbread cookie, blueberry muffin, chicken panini with salad. No choice has gone wrong; all have been fantastic. From what I've seen and read this is a popular coffee spot, but I don't drink coffee so I can't comment on their drink offerings. 

Negative: small indoor space, the line can get backed up with only 1 or 2 employees at a time.

Positive: outdoor seating on the front sidewalk and the quaint enclosed private patio, free wi-fi, co-op kitchen shared by local chefs supports local business and creativity as well as provides fresh goods from Batter Bakery. really, the patio space is a rare and great perk to this experience.

Other: Batter Bakery is based out of the back and sells baked goods at the storefront. The art room in the back is used for Sunday night dinners. Evening offerings are rumored to be coming soon.
author: Heath P.

description: Since I thought I'd gotten a pretty tasty sandwich here in the past, I opted to give it another try. I chose the chicken panini and waited for 30 minutes for my take-out to be done. Once I returned to my office, I opened up my little package to find a dry baguette, a slab of dry chicken breast and a slice of provolone...and that's it. No condiments and no veggies, not ever the roasted peppers that are supposed to be included...and that for over $8. I know the prices have gotten a bit crazy in the Mission over the last couple of years, but at least you usually get a bit of quality to justify the increase. Here, you just get an expensive sandwich that leaves you wanting for taste. I guess I'll nibble on my snickers bar.
author: Heather S.

description:
I have been to the stable cafe twice now, and both times were fabulous. The only reason I did not provide a 5 star rating is the wait, the first time it was a 45 minute wait for my food, the second was about 20. 

My first visit I ordered a bowl of potato soup, and a 3 cheese sandwich. The sandwich had Brie, Swiss( I'm pretty sure it was swiss but this cheese could have been something else), and Provolone. My sandwich was perfectly melty and had a nice crisp bread, the cheeses inside were a heavenly combination. The soup wasn't chunky like a potato soup, which i wasn't expecting, it was more a consistent creamy texture with a hint of curry flavoring, again very fresh tasting. The soup also came with very crunchy little crouton bread pieces which were very flavorful.

The second visit, I ordered a lavender short bread cookie ( based on another yelpers review) the daily quiche, potato soup, and strawberry lemonade.  The cookie is a very unique flavor you really taste the lavender, and its very buttery and smooth. The quiche has olives, potatoes, cheddar, onions and maybe some other things i'm not sure about, but it is incredible! This time the potato soup is the same kind of potato curry combination as the first, with a a lot more spice but not hot, and leeks added. Both versions are good. Now the strawberry lemonade is my favorite part, it is without a doubt the best, freshest tasting strawberry lemonade I have ever consumed. My only complaint about it, is that it was packed with ice so I had way less lemonade to enjoy, other wise I was very happy with my visit and food selections. 
I plan to return to stable cafe often. Also the price for each lunch was about 14 dollars and my first lunch did include a drink as well. 

For those who haven't been here the place itself is very cool, the inside has a little loft area upstairs with additional seating, some tables down stairs, and a nice large outdoor patio space.  If you dine in they have a table near the front with self serve water and glasses. It is very busy at lunch so i have been getting my stuff to go, but in the mornings it would be a nice space to drink a coffee and read.
author: Victoria M.

description:
Wholy Cow in a hand basket!  This place is good, I had the roasted redpepper w/mozzarella on focaccia + a lovely romaine lettuce salad w/tasty unidentifiable salad dressing- whatever it was, I loved it.

I finished it all of with a lavender, salt shortbread cookie ( I am eating this back at my office right now).

The place looks as beautiful as the food tastes, this is going to become one of those places that I dream of on the weekends...  I will look forward to riding my bike the long way to work so I can stop by for tasty fritatta and  coffee treats.

Yay and the gentlemen at the counter was a doll.
author: Sharon S.

description: Stable was a great stumble-in after a workout in the neighborhood. And they had mate on the menu, one of my favorite teas on Earth. I should have written this review sooner because I can't remember what else I had! Oh yeah.. some kind of egg sandwich thing... it was good, but even more than the food, I really liked the space. We sat in the courtyard, which is shared with the surrounding buildings. Perfect for people watching and soaking up some sun. I wouldn't travel across town just to go here, but if I was in the hood I'd definitely stop in.
author: Lesly S.

description:
Wow, what a great space. I swear, the design of the space inside here is really just crazy cool. Really. And somehow it makes the food taste better, not that it needs much help. It's definitely a cute little café to hit up and relax in with friends.

I had the roast beef sandwich and it was really quite tasty, served with a small side salad. I also asked for an au lait (it's not on the menu, but I just asked for it) and it was decidedly creamy and tasty. I'm not sure what kind of coffee they serve here, but it was good stuff (not that I'm a connoisseur). I think they have free refills on the press pot coffee, if that's your thing!
author: Reese W.

description:
All I can say as WOW.  I went to this small cafe for the first time today.  I think it opened just last week.  It was amazing.  The space is really open and cool with great music.  A great place for lunch.  There is a daily special panini  ($6) and soup ($3.50).  (Today's was Fig and Goat cheese panini and Vegetable puree soup.)  I had a roasted bell pepper and mozzarella sandwich on foccacia.  It was delicious and there were several balls of mozzarella.  I counted 9!  To drink I had a hot green tea and also fresh squeezed watermelon juice.  I will definitely be back often.  Go early because the specials sell out fast.

The desserts are made onsite and look incredible.  I had a german chocolate cupcake that was so moist it could have been pudding.  Easily the best cupcake I have ever eaten.  And, I took one of the house special cookies to go.  It is called a "sand angel" and it also was delicious.  It is hard to describe, kinda like a thick sugar cookie with cinnamon and maybe maple.  These cookies are worth the trip alone.  

I havent been for breakfast but it looks like there are homemade scones and breakfast breads  every morning also.
author: Trace W.

description: This place has a really awesome interior and exterior. They have an outdoor seating area and two levels inside. The food is very tasty! I usually get their grilled chicken salad and it is delicious. The reason I'm giving it 3 stars is that 3 out of 5 times they mess up my order (and I've been there over 10 times). I love their salads and I am particular about what I want in it. I generally order the salad on the phone for later pick up and practically every time the order is messed up and I end up picking out onions or carrots or whatever extra stuff they threw in there. It's sort of mind boggling. If you are picky and making a special order, make sure to triple check and then peek at the food before you take it away!
author: Masha S.

description: Very nice cafe but no outlets to charge your laptop...
author: Suzana S.

description: WOW! This place is so trendy. like hipsters and wood and metal and sh*t. I had the quinoa salad, highly recommended, I'll definitely be going back for more. People complain that the food takes a while, get over it, its not mcdonalds and worth the wait.
author: Adriani L.

description: Why can't staff know what's on the menu...I ordered bacon Brie panini and got a chicken sandwich....mind you this is the SAME girl who smile at me whole I ordered it from her...,I've been coming here for a while & yesterday I was just almost over it! The staff can be GOOD (Steph, Jean and the one w/ the glasses)or just overall BAD ( tall chick & tattoo kid) depending on whose working. You know it's bad when you can tell that other staff members doing extra work to balance the new workers....I see that they're going for the pretty & exotic look, but can't they hire people with a brain...The place is pretty sweet and is a nice escape from Valencia st. I just don't want to stop going there. I'll might have to go elsewhere if that dumb Brazilian chick is there.
author: Elena T.

description:
Went to Stable Cafe for lunch and though I loved the atmosphere, I just wasn't wild about the food. Everything sounded so good, but most of the pre-made sandwiches and salads in the case looked tired. 

I thought I'd do better ordering from the daily menu so I got a cold sandwich with ham, swiss, whole grain mustard and fig jam. The cheese looked and tasted like it was sliced from a block quite a few days prior. It was dry and cracked on the edges and didn't taste the freshest. Though the vinaigrette was homemade and tasty, the lettuce was wilted. One friend ordered the quiche (more like a frittata since there was no crust) and said it was just ok. The bean soup/chili looked great though and it was served with thinly sliced walnut toast.

Service was friendly, if slow and confused. I want to go back and have a better experience because I love the space. But this time I left feeling like it was just OK.
author: Crissy G.

description:
I wanted to like this place.
But with all of the cafes popping up in and around the mission, they really need to step up their game.

To be honest this place is probably a 4 star... if this was my neighborhood cafe and I ordered whatever it is that they're good at.

I had only the regular coffee but it was TERRIBLE.
It may or may not be fair to judge a cafe by 1 item, but if you can't make a decent coffee how can I trust anything else from the cafe?

Honestly Stable should just take it off of the menu and then they wouldn't have a quality problem with it.

Stable's coffee had the taste of coffee, only with a lot more to it.
Specs and chucks of bean were present. INSTANT DIURETIC.
(their fancy sugar chunks are quite idiotic by the way)

The staff also had issues with communication.

On the positive side, the space was small but clean and there was a huge(by SF standards) outdoor space on the side of the cafe and a few tables available in the front.
author: Henry C.

description: This is about the catering that Thomas, owner of Stable, provided me for my birthday party. It was outstanding! His help in developing the menu, his ability to make all parts of the process very smooth and easy and his wonderful execution made for a fabulous experience. The food was excellent, as were the agua fresca and sangria that he made. The service provided was excellent and the whole process - which can be a little stressful - was super fun. I'd work with Thomas again in a heartbeat.
author: peter R.

description: Solid lunch (chicken panini) and a very tasty latte.  Cool place. Nice little quiet spot in the city
author: Ryan T.

description: 4 Stars for the building alone! A San Francisco landmark renovated into a sleek modern cafe. Great use of space, light and windows. I love the hip utilitarian feel to the place. Coffee was very good. I actually had my iced coffee black (i usually add sugar and creme). Hints of berry and citrus. Quite yummy. I've yet to try the food but it looked quite fresh, healthy and appetizing. love the patio on the side. Perfect for the surprise sunny SF days.
author: Farah S.

description: I had lunch here yesterday with a few friends.  Its a great place if its nice out, they have a lovely little side garden/yard where you can sit and enjoy your lunch.  It did get a bit crowded and the staff def seemed stressed and not always friendly, esp the guy taking the orders!  Overall it was a good experience - but I would suggest not getting the quich/fratta - didn't have much flavor.  If your in the neighborhood and are hungry on a nice day this is a place to go!  Enjoy!
author: Jennifer M.

description: The location, the space, the food, the drinks, this place is heaven wrapped up in a cafe. Extra nice extra cute extra awesome complete without outdoor umbrella seating. Grab lunch grab a coffee grab a snack.
author: Skye W.

description: I love everything about this place.  The coffee is amazing and the yogurt and granola is the best that I have ever had!
author: Laura P.

description:
Lunch review:  Chill place, but hoping it gets better on next visit.

Highlights:
- Delicious empanadas (esp. the corn) from venge
- Yummy side salad
- Amazing strawberry agua fresca
- Daily specials that keep me wanting to come back
- Quinoa salad that others ordered looks amazing
- Charming space


Downsides:
- There were a good number of flies in the restaurant hovering in the main space (hoping it was because of the weather and the open door)
- Kind of traps noise- there were 2 women today having a excruciating conversation about the porn industry / web video sites that made me want to gag.  I wish I remembered sooner I had headphones.  C'mon, this is not appropriate conversation to have in a cafe!
- Service was a little bit slow and off-kilter.

Next time, I'll get a quinoa salad, the daily agua fresca and a cookie to finish up!
author: Jeff A.

description:
40 min wait for a cold sandwich ??

I understand lunch can be a busy time, but really ?  - There's coffee bar a few blocks away that does equally amazing sandwiches if not better.

In my mind, here's how the s/w was prepared

1. Take 2 slices of bread
2. Apply mustard on one side
3. Place already cooked pork along with some greens
4. Slice into half.

Sorry, this doesn't take 40 min and it wasn't even super crowded. One word - Mismanagement.

Good coffee though !
author: Rooibos T.

description: We had a NERT drill at the SFFD training center, so this was a convenient spot for our group to get together for a recap. Party of 9 off the street at 1:30, we were able to commandeer several tables upstairs and it proved the perfect spot for our gathering. The ordering line was a bit cumbersome but not overly so, and there were plenty of cupcakes buzzing around to make it interesting. I had the chicken sandwich (very good), followed by a macchiato (very good) and a cookie (amazing). Prices are good and the vibe is cool. Extra points for the sunny day.
author: Robert M.

description: Had a wonderful lunch here today and I can't wait to go back. The food was fresh, creative, and all locally sourced--just fantastic. The outdoor space is gorgeous; we sat outside and had a glass of wine and ate the quinoa salad, which was fabulous and just the right amount of food. A truly great place to while away an afternoon.
author: Tricia K.

description: The coffee and food are great but the atmosphere can be a little hectic.  There are also no outlets for laptops so make sure your battery is fully charged before going!
author: Jay R.

description:
I went there this morning for quick breakfast on my way to work. Definite mistake. 

The coffee was horrible, somehow managing to be both watery and bitter and I waited a good twenty minutes for my egg sandwich. The food was fine, but the wait and terrible coffee crushed the experience.
